questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to the office for the evaluation of absent menses. The patient has not had a menstrual period yet but is otherwise healthy. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows appropriate breast development and growth of pubic and underarm hair. The patient declined a vaginal exam. Karyotype analysis reveals 46 XX. Pregnancy test is negative; thyroid stimulating hormone, prolactin, luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels are normal. Pelvic ultrasound shows 2 normal-sized ovaries but no uterus. Which of the following is the most likely underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Defective conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with primary amenorrhea, normal development of secondary sexual characteristics, and an absent uterus is consistent with Müllerian agenesis.

Müllerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome, results from the failure of mullerian duct development. The Müllerian duct system is responsible for the development of the uterus, cervix and upper two thirds of the vagina, so these organs may be absent, or rudimentary and obstructed, which explains the absence of menses. The ovaries develop normally in these individuals, and the ovarian follicles make normal amounts of estrogen and progesterone; therefore, patients develop normal secondary sexual characteristics (e.g., breast development, axillary and public hair). FSH and LH levels are also within normal limits.



Option Analysis

❌ Defective conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone:
Incorrect: 5-alpha reductase converts testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. Deficiency of this enzyme causes female external genitalia and male internal genitalia to develop. Such patients have a male karyotype (i.e 46 XY). This patient’s karyotype reveals 46 XX, and she has female internal genitalia (ovaries).
❌ Gonadotropin-releasing hormone deficiency:
Incorrect:  Kallman syndrome, an X-linked disorder resulting from the failure of migration of fetal olfactory and GnRH producing neurons, causes hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Secondary sexual characteristics are not well developed (unlike this patient with normal breasts and pubic hair).
✅ Failure of mullerian duct formation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Loss of an X chromosome:
Incorrect: Turner syndrome results from nondisjunction of sex chromosomes during meiosis. The patients have low estrogen levels leading to amenorrhea and absent breast development. Pelvic ultrasound shows small ovaries (unlike the normal sized ovaries seen in this patient).
❌ Defect in androgen receptor function:
Incorrect: Androgen insensitivity syndrome results from a defect in androgen receptor function. Although the patients do not have a uterus, pubic and axillary hair are also absent. Moreover, such patients are karyotypically male (i.e 46 XY).

questions.text:
A 6-week-old infant boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for evaluation of an abdominal bulge. His mother noticed the protrusion a few days ago while bathing him. The patient is exclusively breastfed and produces 6-7 wet diapers per day. According to his mother, the patient has had no vomiting, diarrhea, or constipation. He is at the 65th percentile for both height and weight. Examination of the patient’s abdomen reveals the following:
 

Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following best accounts for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Impaired lateral wall migration during embryologic development
Incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct
Incomplete closure of the processus vaginalis
Impaired fusion of the pleuroperitoneal membranes

questions.solution:
This patient has a congenital umbilical hernia, which occurs when the intestines herniate through a weakened umbilical fibromuscular ring. However, unlike an omphalocele or gastroschisis, the intestines are fully covered by skin, and the hernia looks like a protruding bulge from the belly button. The bulge can enlarge when intra-abdominal pressure is increased, such as when coughing or crying.  

Most umbilical hernias are asymptomatic and 90% self-resolve within the first 2-5 years of life. However, a large hernia can cause bowel strangulation, resulting in ischemia and necrosis.

Option Analysis

❌ Impaired lateral wall migration during embryologic development :
Incorrect: An omphalocele occurs when the lateral folds fail to migrate and fuse at the umbilical ring. It manifests as herniated abdominal contents surrounded by a layer of peritoneum. In contrast, no abdominal contents with peritoneum are seen herniating from this patient. 
❌ Incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct :
Incorrect: This answer describes a Meckel diverticulum. While largely asymptomatic, this condition can cause gastrointestinal bleeding and abdominal pain. However, it would be atypical for a Meckel diverticulum to manifest as a protruding mass at the anterior abdomen. 
❌ Incomplete closure of the processus vaginalis :
Incorrect: This pathophysiology leads to the formation of an indirect inguinal hernia, which can present as a bulge in the groin. However, this patient’s bulge is at the umbilicus. 
❌ Impaired fusion of the pleuroperitoneal membranes :
Incorrect: This answer describes a diaphragmatic hernia. It can cause intra-abdominal contents to enter the thoracic cavity and impair lung development. As a result, patients can develop respiratory distress. In addition, patients can present with a scaphoid abdomen (flattened abdomen) since a sizable amount of the intra-abdominal contents have shifted into the chest. In contrast, none of these findings are observed in this patient. 
✅ Weakened umbilical fibromuscular ring :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to his outpatient provider seeking evaluation for intermittent groin pain. The pain is worse when he is lifting weights in the gym and improves with rest. Past medical history is notable for seasonal allergies. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg, and pulse is 67/min. Physical exam reveals a left-sided bulge in the groin that increases in size with coughing and Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Acquired weakness of the transversalis fascia
Incomplete obliteration of the processus vaginalis

questions.solution:
This patient has an indirect inguinal hernia. It occurs when the processus vaginalis, an embryonic outpouching of the peritoneum, fails to obliterate, and a portion of the intestines is able to herniate into the inguinal canal. Indirect inguinal hernias manifest as a bulge that is lateral to the lower epigastric vessels. It passes through both the internal and external inguinal rings.  

A similar condition is direct inguinal hernia. It is often seen in elderly men and caused by weakened abdominal muscles and fascia. The condition manifests as a bulge medial to the lower epigastric vessels and passes through only the external inguinal ring.  

Both conditions can cause groin pain, especially when there is increased abdominal pressure. In males, the intestine can protrude into the scrotum, causing pain and a sensation of fullness in the testicles. If bowel strangulation occurs, there will be acute-onset abdominal pain accompanied by nausea, vomiting and possibly fever.  


Option Analysis

❌ Acquired weakness of the transversalis fascia:
Incorrect: This answer describes a direct inguinal hernia, which is most often seen in elderly men. In contrast, it would be atypical for a direct inguinal hernia to manifest in an otherwise healthy teenager. 
❌  Impaired fusion of the pleuroperitoneal membranes :
Incorrect: Impaired fusion of the pleuroperitoneal membranes results in a diaphragmatic hernia. This defect can allow abdominal contents to herniate into the thoracic cavity. However, this patient’s hernia is located in the groin.  
✅ Incomplete obliteration of the processus vaginalis :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Weakness of the linea alba :
Incorrect: This pathology causes an epigastric hernia, which can manifest anywhere between the xiphoid process and umbilicus. However, an epigastric hernia would not manifest as a bulge in the groin. 
❌  Widening of the femoral ring :
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathophysiology of a femoral hernia, which can present as a palpable mass found below the inguinal ligament. The condition is most commonly diagnosed in middle-aged females. In contrast, it would be atypical for a femoral hernia to present in a young male.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman is being evaluated for recurrent urinary tract infections. During the past year, she had 4 urinary tract infections, each of which required antibiotics. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. The patient does not use tobacco, excessive alcohol, or illicit substances. She is in a monogamous relationship with her partner of 15 years. She works as a computer programmer and lives with her partner and 2 children. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Intravenous urography is performed, and the results are shown below:  

Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons 

The doctor explains to the patient that the condition occured due to abnormal development of the embryonic kidneys. At which developmental phase did the patient's condition most likely occur?

choices.text: Development of the ureteric bud from the nephrogenic cord
Growth of the ureteric bud into the ureteric stalk
Ureteric bud lengthening and secretion of growth factors
Ureteric bud growing within the metanephric mesoderm

questions.solution:
This patient has recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs), which raises concern for an underlying condition. The intravenous urography imaging shows two ureters coming out of the left kidney, confirming the diagnosis of a duplex collecting system.   

During embryonic development, the intermediate mesoderm condenses to form a cylindrical structure called the urogenital ridge. The portion of the urogenital ridge called the nephrogenic cord eventually gives rise to the metanephros, which forms the ureteric buds. Overtime, the ureteric buds lengthen and secrete growth factors that cause the metanephric mesoderm (also termed metanephric mesenchyme) to grow in a process termed reciprocal induction. The metanephric mesoderm gives rise to the glomeruli, proximal tubules, loop of Henle, and distal convoluted tubule. The ureteric bud develops into the collecting system, minor and major calyces, renal pelvis, and ureters.  

A duplex collecting system can occur via 2 mechanisms. First, bifurcation of the ureteric bud before it enters the metanephric blastema results in a Y-shaped bifid ureter (partial duplication). Second, two ureteric buds develop and interact with the metanephric blastema, resulting in 2 seperate collecting systems, as seen here (complete duplication).  

Duplex collecting systems can be asymptomatic or present with urinary tract infections, hydronephrosis, and vesicoureteral reflux. In symptomatic patients, referral to a urologist is warranted for surgical repair.  

Option Analysis

✅ Development of the ureteric bud from the nephrogenic cord:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Growth of the ureteric bud into the ureteric stalk:
Incorrect: The growth of the ureteric bud into the urteretic stalk forms the future ureter. Duplication of the collecting system can occur at this phase if the ureteric bud were to split in two before reaching and interacting with the metanephric blastema. However, this pathway would lead to a Y-shaped bifid ureter, rather than the two separate ureters seen on imaging.  
❌ Ureteric bud lengthening and secretion of growth factors:
Incorrect: The ureteric bud lengthening and secretion of growth factors causes the metanephric blastema to grow. Eventually, the ureteric bud reaches the metanephric mesoderm and grows into it. A duplex collecting system would not be formed at this step.  
❌ Ureteric bud growing within the metanephric mesoderm:
Incorrect: As the ureteric bud grows within the metanephric mesoderm, the ureteric bud divides in half to form the renal pelvis. Each renal pelvis then divides in half to form two major calyces. A duplex collecting system would not be formed at this step.

questions.text: A 24-year-old gravida 1 para 0 woman at 27 weeks of gestation comes to the office for evaluation of a low amniotic fluid index discovered on a biophysical profile. The pregnancy has been complicated by gestational diabetes mellitus. The patient is currently on an insulin regimen. Fetal ultrasonography shows bilateral absence of the kidneys. The doctor explains to the mother that this is most likely due to aberrant interaction between the ureteric bud and metanephric mesenchyme. Which of the following structures does the ureteric bud give rise to under normal conditions?
questions.solution:
The fetus has bilateral kidney agenesis, a pathology incompatible with life. The absence of amniotic fluid causes severe pulmonary hypoplasia and respiratory insufficiency at birth. In contrast, unilateral agenesis is compatible with life, since the single kidney is able to compensate for the missing one.  

During embryonic development, the intermediate mesoderm condenses to form a cylindrical structure called the urogenital ridge. The portion of the urogenital ridge called the nephrogenic cord eventually gives rise to the metanephros, which forms the ureteric buds. Overtime, the ureteric buds lengthen and secrete growth factors that cause the metanephric mesoderm (also termed metanephric mesenchyme) to grow in a process termed reciprocal induction. The metanephric mesoderm gives rise to the glomeruli, proximal tubules, loop of Henle, and distal convoluted tubule. The ureteric bud develops into the collecting system, minor and major calyces, renal pelvis, and ureters.  

If the ureteric buds fail to develop, renal agenesis occurs. In contrast, if the ureteric buds develop but fail to induce differentiation of the metanephric mesoderm, then multicystic dysplastic kidney disease occurs.    





Option Analysis

❌ Glomeruli :
Incorrect: The glomeruli arise from the metanephric mesoderm. Please see the “Main Explanation” for additional information.   
❌ Proximal convoluted tubule:
Incorrect: The proximal convoluted tubule is derived from the metanephric mesoderm. Please see the “Main Explanation” for additional information.   
❌ Loop of Henle :
Incorrect: The Loop of Henle is derived from the metanephric mesoderm. Please see the “Main Explanation” for additional information.   
❌ Distal convoluted tubule:
Incorrect: The distal convoluted tubule is derived from the metanephric mesoderm. Please see the “Main Explanation” for additional information.   
✅ Collecting system:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 2-week-old male is brought to the emergency department due to vomiting and lethargy. The patient has had several days of difficulty feeding, frequent spitting, and poor weight gain. His mother is worried that he might be dehydrated. The patient was born at home and did not have any prenatal screening performed. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 182/min, respirations are 70/min, blood pressure is 40/19 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. On physical exam the infant has poor tone, sunken fontanelles, and dry mucous membranes. Initial laboratory findings are demonstrated below:



Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This neonate presents with dehydration, shock, and adrenal insufficiency as evidenced by hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypoglycemia. These findings raise concern for 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which is associated with elevated renin levels due to absence of suppression of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.  

21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, which are a series of autosomal recessive enzymatic deficiency disorders that disrupt synthesis of mineralocorticoids, glucocorticoids, and sex hormones. 21-hydroxylase deficiency causes decreased glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid synthesis and elevated precursors--the most important of which is 17-hydroxyprogesterone, which is used for the diagnosis of this condition. Ultimately, cortisol and aldosterone are not produced in this disorder, resulting in elevated levels of renin, ACTH, and increased production of androgen precursors.  

21-hydroxylase deficiency has differing clinical manifestations depending on the degree of enzyme deficiency and sex at birth. In severe deficiency, both male and female infants present with significant salt-wasting syndrome characterized by shock, dehydration, and adrenal crisis. Most female neonates will have ambiguous genitalia at birth due to androgen excess. Moderate deficiency will result in ambiguous genitalia in females, whereas males will demonstrate early virilization (at age 2-4) due to androgen excess. Mild enzyme deficiency will result in hirsutism and menstrual irregularities in females, whereas males develop early-onset puberty.  

The majority of patients born in the developed world are screened after birth by measuring 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels. Diagnosis of the disorder is achieved through screening for adrenal insufficiency and enzymatic activity assays. Treatment involves life-long replacement of gluco- and mineralocorticoids.



Option Analysis

✅ Increased renin activity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased renin activity:
Incorrect: Decreased renin activity is associated with 11ꞵ-hydroxylase and 17α-hydroxylase deficiency. These conditions lead to elevated levels of hormones with mild mineralocorticoid activity (e.g., 11-deoxycorticosterone, aldosterone), resulting in hypertension, hypokalemia, and suppression of the renin-angiotensin axis.
❌ Decreased levels of androstenedione  :
Incorrect: Decreased levels of androstenedione are associated with 17α-hydroxylase deficiency, which manifests with ambiguous genitalia in males and lack of secondary sex characteristics in females.
❌ Increased levels of 11-deoxycorticosterone and corticosterone:
Incorrect: Elevated levels of 11-deoxycorticosterone and corticosterone are observed in 17α-hydroxylase deficiency due to shunting of pregnenolone towards aldosterone production. This disorder manifests with hypokalemia and hypertension. In contrast, this patient has hyperkalemia and hypotension.
❌ Increased levels of 11-deoxycorticosterone only:
Incorrect: Elevated levels of 11-deoxycorticosterone without elevated levels of corticosterone are observed in patients with 11ꞵ-hydroxylase deficiency, which manifests with hypokalemia and hypertension. In contrast, this patient has hyperkalemia and hypotension.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents to the physician accompanied by his parent for a routine visit. The patient has repeatedly failed reading comprehension and mathematics tests in school. The patient was born at an advanced maternal age of 42. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient is at the 89th percentile for height. On physical examination, the patient is noted to have gynecomastia, long extremities, and testicular hypoplasia. A mid-systolic click is auscultated most prominently over the cardiac apex. Which of the following best describes this patient’s chromosomal abnormality?
questions.solution:
This patient exhibits poor school performance, gynecomastia, long extremities, testicular hypoplasia, and mitral valve prolapse (as evidenced by the mid-systolic click). He was born to a mother with advanced maternal age (age 36 and higher). In combination, these findings are concerning for Klinefelter syndrome (XXY).  

Advanced maternal age is a major risk factor for the development of chromosomal abnormalities. Studies have demonstrated that as women become older, age-dependent changes in the sister chromatid cohesion complex that form during meiosis I are responsible for aberrancies in chromosomal translocation. Specifically, proteins responsible for pairing the chromatids, such as SMC1 Beta, have decreased function with advanced maternal age.  

 There are five main chromosomal disorders associated with advanced maternal age, and they include the trisomies (21, 18, and 13), Triple X syndrome, and Klinefelter syndrome. Down syndrome (trisomy 21) is the most common autosomal chromosome abnormality associated with increased maternal age.  

 There are four main chromosomal abnormalities associated with the sex chromosomes. These include Klinefelter syndrome, Turner syndrome, Triple X syndrome (XXX), and Jacobs syndrome (XYY). Among these four disorders, Klinefelter Syndrome is the most prevalent.  

Of note, Turner syndrome and Jacobs syndrome are typically caused by meiotic nondisjunction of the paternal gametes. As a result, these conditions are not associated with advanced maternal age.  

Option Analysis

❌ Trisomy 21  :
 Incorrect: Down syndrome is the most common chromosomal abnormality associated with advanced maternal age. The condition can also present with intellectual disability. However, this patient has long limbs, gynecomastia, and a cardiac murmur suggestive of mitral valve prolapse. In combination, these findings are more suggestive of Klinefelter syndrome (XXY).  
❌ XXX:
 Incorrect: Individuals with triple X syndrome have a female phenotype. The condition can range from being asymptomatic to presenting with an unusually tall stature, developmental delays, and learning disabilities. In contrast, the child in this vignette is phenotypically male.   
❌ XO:
 Incorrect: Turner syndrome presents with delayed puberty, short stature, heart defects, infertility, and learning disabilities. Individuals with Turner syndrome will have a female phenotype. In contrast, the patient in this vignette has tall stature and a male phenotype.   
✅ XXY:
 Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ XYY:
 Incorrect: XYY syndrome, also termed double Y syndrome and Jacobs syndrome, is not the same as Klinefelter syndrome, although the two are quite similar. XYY syndrome can present with tall stature, intellectual disability, and severe acne. However, XYY syndrome would not typically cause small testicles or mitral valve prolapse.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the office by his parent due to abnormal body movements. His parent states that the patient has been walking abnormally for the past several weeks with frequent falls. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 108/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. Physical examination reveals multidirectional, nonrhythmic eye movements. The patient is also observed to have sporadic limb jerkings and truncal ataxia when walking. A left-sided immobile abdominal mass is palpated. There is no hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory testing reveals anemia, and elevated levels of homovanillic acid and vanillylmandelic acid are detected in the urine. The abdominal mass most likely originated from which of the following embryologic derivatives?
questions.solution:
This young boy is presenting with an abdominal mass, opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome, and elevated urinary catecholamine metabolites. He most likely has a neuroblastoma. Neuroblastomas are malignant tumors of the sympathetic nervous system. They are composed of poorly differentiated “neuroblasts,” which originate from the neural crest, and they can occur anywhere in the sympathetic chain or adrenal medulla.

A classic paraneoplastic syndrome called the opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia (OMA) syndrome, or “dancing eye syndrome,” can be present in some patients. This syndrome is a neurological disorder consisting of three main symptoms: 1) opsoclonus, which are multidirectional, chaotic eye movements, 2) myoclonus, which are nonepileptic limb jerkings that can also involve the head and face, and 3) truncal ataxia, which causes gait imbalance. Almost 50% of children with OMA syndrome have an underlying neuroblastoma; therefore all children presenting with OMA syndrome should be evaluated for neuroblastoma.





Option Analysis

✅ Neural crest:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Endoderm:
Incorrect: The endoderm gives rise to all structures derived from the inner lining of the primitive gut tube. Organs such as the stomach, liver, and intestines all arise from the endoderm. Although this patient is presenting with an abdominal mass, another embryologic derivative gives rise to neuroblastomas.
❌ Mesoderm:
Incorrect: The mesoderm gives rise to bones, muscles, visceral tissues, and many organs (e.g., kidneys, adrenal cortex, testes, ovaries). Although a Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma) can present as an abdominal mass, this patient’s opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome is more consistent with the presentation of a neuroblastoma.
❌ Neuroectoderm:
Incorrect: The neuroectoderm gives rise to the central nervous system and preganglionic autonomic neurons. It is not, however, the origin of neuroblastoma.
❌ Surface ectoderm:
Incorrect: The surface ectoderm gives rise to the outer layer of many organs (e.g., lens of eye, epithelial linings of oral cavity), as well as the sweat and mammary glands. Additionally, it is the origin of craniopharyngiomas in children, which present as an anterior pituitary mass. However, the surface ectoderm is not the origin of neuroblastomas, which classically present with the opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 10-day-old boy is brought to his primary pediatrician for his first newborn evaluation. Since birth, he has had persistent swelling of his scrotum. He was born at 39 weeks gestation following an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. He has been breastfeeding multiple times throughout the day and is making 8-9 wet diapers a day with normal stooling. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals bilateral descended testicles that are palpable in the scrotum. There is a visibly enlarged, fluctuant left hemiscrotum. A penlight is held behind the left hemiscrotum, which demonstrates transillumination. Which of the following best describes the underlying etiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Patent processus vaginalis with peritoneal communication
Excessive production of fluid from the tunica vaginalis
Bowel protrusion through the inguinal canal
Impaired lymphatic drainage of scrotal structures
Malignant proliferation of testicular germ cells

questions.solution:
A hydrocele is an abnormal collection of serous fluid between the two layers (visceral and parietal) of the tunica vaginalis of the testis.

There are four mechanisms that may result in the development of a hydrocele:

  1.  Connection with the peritoneal cavity through a patent processus vaginalis (congenital) 
  2.  Excessive production of fluid by the visceral and parietal layers of the tunica vaginalis (secondary hydrocele) 
  3.  Defective absorption of fluid by the parietal layer of the tunica vaginalis 
  4.  Impaired lymphatic drainage of scrotal structures, such as in filarial hydroceles 
This neonate likely has a congenital hydrocele, which results from failure of the processus vaginalis to obliterate. During development, the testes are formed retroperitoneally and descend into the scrotum via the inguinal canal. Normally, the proximal portion of the processus vaginalis obliterates while the distal portion persists as the tunica vaginalis. Therefore, the tunica vaginalis becomes a potential space for fluid collection. In the case of a patent processus vaginalis, peritoneal fluid is allowed to move into the scrotum, forming a hydrocele.

A characteristic feature of hydroceles is their ability to transilluminate. An ultrasound, although not necessary for diagnosis, typically reveals an anechoic or echolucent area surrounding the testis. Most primary causes of hydrocele require no surgery. Congenital hydroceles tend to resolve spontaneously by the end of the first year of life.  
 

Option Analysis

✅ Patent processus vaginalis with peritoneal communication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Excessive production of fluid from the tunica vaginalis:
Incorrect: Inflammatory intrascrotal conditions, such as epididymitis and/or orchitis can lead to secondary or reactive hydroceles, caused by excessive fluid production from the mesothelial lining of the tunica vaginalis. This healthy-appearing neonate has no signs of an inflammatory process, making this etiology less likely.
❌ Bowel protrusion through the inguinal canal:
Incorrect: This answer describes an inguinal hernia. Physical examination usually reveals an inguinal mass that is worsened with increased abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, Valsalva maneuver) and may extend to the scrotum; however, hernias do not transilluminate, making this etiology less likely.
❌ Impaired lymphatic drainage of scrotal structures:
Incorrect: Interference with the lymphatic drainage of scrotal structures can be seen in filarial hydroceles. Bancroftian filariasis is a mosquito-borne parasitic disease. In filarial hydroceles, the parasitic organisms obstruct the fluid absorption by the draining lymphatic vessels of the parietal layer (part of the tunica vaginalis), resulting in fluid accumulation and subsequent formation of a hydrocele. This child has no risk factors for acquiring filarial hydrocele, making this etiology unlikely.
❌ Malignant proliferation of testicular germ cells:
Incorrect: Testicular germ cell tumors can be seen in neonates. Patients typically have evidence of a palpable testicular lump; however, tumors do not transilluminate.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the office with her mother for a routine health checkup. The patient has not had a menstrual period yet but is otherwise healthy.  She wears corrective spectacles for myopia. The patient performs well academically and plays the flute in her school’s marching band. The patient’s height and weight are at 5th and 60th percentile, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 150/85 mmHg in the right upper arm and 90/65 mmHg in the left upper arm. Physical examination shows a Tanner stage I breast with widely-spaced nipples. Serum FSH is 65 mU/mL. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This adolescent has primary amenorrhea, which is defined as absence of menses at age 13 years in the absence of secondary sexual characteristics (i.e. Tanner stage I breast). This finding, in combination with short stature, widely spaced nipples, and elevated FSH levels, is consistent with Turner syndrome (TS).

Turner syndrome is a sporadic chromosomal disorder that usually results from nondisjunction of sex chromosomes during meiosis. Roughly half of the individuals have a 45, X0 karyotype, whereas the other half have a mosaic of either 45 X0 and 46 XX or a mosaic of 45 X0 and 46 XY. The syndrome is characterized by short stature, a wide or webbed neck, a broad chest with widely spaced nipples, low-set ears, as well as arms that turn outward at the elbows. The patients have low estrogen levels due to the loss of ovarian function, leading to amenorrhea and absent breast development. Low estrogen levels prevent negative feedback on the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian (HPO) axis, leading to increased FSH and LH production.



The adrenal glands, however, are not affected, and thus the patients can have normal adrenarche. Additional features can include coarctation of aorta (which can cause asymmetric blood pressures), bicuspid aortic valve, horseshoe kidneys, hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities.   

Option Analysis

❌ Severe calorie restriction and deficiency:
Incorrect: Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea occurs in females with severe calorie restriction and nutrient deficiency due to the suppression of hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. FSH and LH are low in this condition. This patient’s FSH is elevated.
✅ Loss of an X chromosome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Failure of mullerian duct formation:
Incorrect: Failure of mullerian duct formation results in mullerian agenesis. This condition is characterized by the failure of the formation of the uterus, cervix and upper vagina.  Patients usually have normal secondary sexual characteristics (e.g. breast development and normal stature). Ovarian development is normal.
❌ Failure of follicle maturation:
Incorrect: The imbalance of LH/FSH ratio in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) can result in the failure of follicle maturation and oocyte release. PCOS is characterized by hyperandrogenism (e.g. acne and hirsutism) or biochemically with elevated testosterone levels. Menstrual irregularities and infertility can also be seen. Ovaries appear polycystic on ultrasound.
❌ Congenital GnRH deficiency:
Incorrect: Kallman syndrome, an X-linked disorder, results from the failure of migration of fetal olfactory and GnRH producing neurons, leading to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Serum FSH and LH levels are decreased (unlike this patient).

questions.text: A 5-month-old female infant is admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit for surgical treatment of preductal coarctation of the aorta. The patient is stable and afebrile. Blood pressure is 70/50 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 34/min. During subsequent evaluation, the patient is found to have a horseshoe kidney as well as lymphedema affecting the hands and feet. The patient has low set ears. Which of the following is the most likely genetic aberration that led to this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Partial loss of chromosome during mitosis

questions.solution:
This vignette describes a female infant with several congenital anomalies, namely preductal coarctation of the aorta, horseshoe kidney, and lymphedema. These findings are suggestive of Turner syndrome.  

Answering this question requires an understanding of the different types of chromosomal abnormalities present within Turner syndrome (see table below). A complete lack of Y chromosomal inheritance, which often occurs due to a nondisjunction during meiosis of the paternal gamete, would lead to the 45 XO genotype. Affected patients will present with the most severe form of Turner syndrome and likely have multiple congenital anomalies, as in the case of this patient.  

In contrast, if Turner syndrome were to develop due to nondisjunction during mitosis, then chromosomal mosaicism would develop. Chromosomal mosaicism means that different cells in the patient’s body will have varying genotypes (e.g., 45 XO, 46 XX).  

Clinical features of Turner syndrome include a female phenotype with webbed neck, shield chest, short stature, lymphedema, nail dysplasia, and high-arched palate. Turner syndrome presents with gonadal dysgenesis and streak ovaries, which results in insufficient estrogen production. As a result, patients can have delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, osteoporosis, and infertility. Furthermore, patients are at risk for coarctation of the aorta and renal malformations.  



Option Analysis

✅ Nondisjunction event during meiosis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nondisjunction event during mitosis  :
Incorrect: While this event would also result in Turner syndrome, it would result in a mosaic form of the condition. The mosaic form of Turner syndrome has far less severe symptoms due to the expression of normal 46 XX chromosomes in some cells. In contrast, the patient in this vignette has multiple congenital abnormalities and likely has a uniform genotype of 45 XO within all cells.
❌ Partial loss of chromosome during mitosis  :
Incorrect: This event would also result in a mosaic form of Turner syndrome, which is far less severe due to the expression of normal 46 XX chromosomes in some cells. This patient has the severe form, as demonstrated by the multiple congenital abnormalities, and likely has a uniform genotype of 45 XO within all cells.  
❌ Nondisjunction resulting in Trisomy 21   :
Incorrect: Individuals with Trisomy 21 can present with low set ears, a single palmar crease, short ears, and short neck. While individuals with trisomy 21 may develop cardiac defects (e.g. atrioventricular septal defects), the condition is not typically associated with coarctation of the aorta.  
❌ Nondisjunction resulting in Trisomy 18  :
Incorrect: Edwards syndrome can present with clenched hands, an abnormally small head, underdeveloped jaw, and rocker bottom feet. However, the condition would not typically present with the combination of coarctation of the aorta, lymphedema, and horseshoe kidney.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida woman at 24 weeks of gestation comes to the office for a routine prenatal evaluation. The pregnancy has been uncomplicated, and she has been compliant with prenatal care. She takes vitamins as needed. Family and medical history are unremarkable. She did not have prior abortions or miscarriages. During ultrasound examination of the fetus, male external genitalia are visible, as well as bilateral hydronephrosis. An amniotic fluid index is equivocal. Which of the following is most likely the cause for the abnormal findings?

choices.text: Failure of urethral folds to fuse
Abnormal positioning of the genital tubercle
Incomplete fusion of the labioscrotal folds
Failure of the urachus to obliterate

questions.solution:
This primigravida fetus has bilateral hydronephrosis, which raises suspicion for a urinary tract anomaly. Posterior urethral valves are the most common etiology of urinary tract obstruction in newborn males.     Posterior urethral valve (PUV) is a congenital disorder in males wherein the posterior urethra, which is the section of the urethra nearest the bladder, is obstructed by membranous folds of tissue. The exact pathogenesis is unclear, but the following mechanisms have been proposed:    

  •  Patency of the urogenital membrane with abnormal canalization of the urethra. 
  •  Overgrowth of urethrovesicular folds. 
  •  Abnormal union of the Wolffian duct into the posterior urethra. 
Prenatal ultrasonographic findings suggestive of PUV include bilateral hydronephrosis, dilated bladder, bladder wall thickening, and a dilated posterior urethra (keyhole sign). In severe cases of obstruction, oligohydramnios may develop. Postnatally, infants may present with respiratory distress due to lung hypoplasia from low amounts of amniotic fluid. Other signs and symptoms include abdominal distension, difficulty voiding, a poor urinary stream, and urinary tract infections. The condition is frequently accompanied by vesicoureteral reflux, secondary to increased intravesical pressure.    Prenatally, diagnosis can be made with ultrasound. Postnatally, diagnosis can be made by a voiding cystourethrogram demonstrating a dilated and elongated posterior urethra with a thin linear defect during the voiding phase. Definitive treatment involves surgical ablation of the membrane.      



Option Analysis

❌ Failure of urethral folds to fuse:
Incorrect: Failure of the urethral folds to fuse would cause hypospadias, an abnormal opening of the penile urethra on the ventral surface of penis. It is typically diagnosed at birth and is associated with cryptorchidism. It would not cause bilateral hydronephrosis.   
❌ Abnormal positioning of the genital tubercle:
Incorrect: Abnormal positioning of the genital tubercle can cause epispadias, an abnormal opening of the penile urethra on the dorsal surface of penis. It is associated with bladder exstrophy, which would be seen on ultrasound. However, the condition would not cause bilateral hydronephrosis.   
✅ Persistence of the urogenital membrane :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Incomplete fusion of the labioscrotal folds:
Incorrect: Incomplete fusion of the labioscrotal folds is the cause of bifid scrotum, which presents as a deep midline cleft in the scrotum. However, bifid scrotum is not associated with bilateral hydronephrosis.   
❌ Failure of the urachus to obliterate:
Incorrect: Failure of the urachus to obliterate would result in a patent urachus, which would allow urine to travel from the bladder to the umbilicus. The condition would cause urine to be discharged from the umbilicus and is usually identified at birth. It would not, however, cause bilateral hydronephrosis.

questions.text: A 9-year-old female is brought to her pediatrician for evaluation of acne. The patient has been doing well in school and has not had any recent infections or health issues. However, she has been having worsening acne despite over the counter treatments. She has no previous medical problems and does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 152/71 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physician exam is notable for moderate facial acne, scant facial hair, and increased upper body muscle tone for age. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This female patient presents with signs of virilization (when a female develops males sex characteristics), as well as worsening acne and hypertension. These findings are concerning for 11β-hydroxylase deficiency.  

11β-hydroxylase deficiency is a subtype of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, which are a series of autosomal recessive enzymatic deficiency disorders that affect mineralocorticoid, glucocorticoid, and sex hormone synthesis. 11β-hydroxylase deficiency results in elevated levels of 11-deoxycorticosterone, which acts as a mild mineralocorticoid, inducing hypertension, hypokalemia, and suppression of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone axis. In addition, steroid precursors are shunted towards androgen production, resulting in virilization in females.  

Clinically, this diagnosis is difficult to distinguish from 21-hydroxylase deficiency. A useful memory tool to recall the difference between these two disorders is if the deficient enzyme starts with 1, it causes hypertension; if the deficient enzyme ends with 1, it causes virilization in females.  

The diagnosis of 11β-hydroxylase deficiency is confirmed by elevations of 11-deoxycortisol and 11-deoxycorticosterone, which are the substrates for 11β-hydroxylase. Management involves glucocorticoid replacement, with or without mineralocorticoid replacement.  



Option Analysis

✅ 11ꞵ-hydroxylase deficiency:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 21-hydroxylase deficiency:
Incorrect: 21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. It commonly presents with virilization in females. However, 21-hydroxylase deficiency presents with signs of hypotension and adrenal insufficiency, not hypertension as in this patient.
❌ 17α-hydroxylase deficiency:
Incorrect: 17α-hydroxylase deficiency is due to shunting of pregnenolone towards aldosterone production. This disorder manifests with hypokalemia and hypertension. Females with this condition will also lack development of secondary sexual characteristics. The condition will not cause symptoms of hyperandrogenism.
❌ 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency:
Incorrect: 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency results in decreased concentrations of aldosterone, cortisol, and androstenedione, with a subsequent increase in the concentrations of renin, ACTH, and dehydroepiandrosterone. However, the condition would not cause hypertension and rarely manifests with virilization in females.
❌ Cholesterol side-chain cleavage enzyme deficiency:
Incorrect: Cholesterol side-chain cleavage (SCC) enzyme deficiency is a rare and lethal form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. It affects the first and rate-limiting step in the steroidogenic pathway and  manifests with mineralocorticoid deficiency in affected infants and children. Male infants are severely undervirilized, causing their external genitalia to look feminine. In contrast, it would be unusual for this condition to cause virilization in a female child.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents due to abnormal tissue “coming out of her vagina.” The patient was born via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. Vaccinations are up to date. She has reached all developmental milestones. There is no family history of genetic conditions or malignancy. In the office, the patient’s temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 81/min, and blood pressure is 105/68 mmHg. On physical examination, the child is playing comfortably and in no acute distress. Vaginal examination reveals multiple polyp-like structures protruding through the vaginal introitus. This lesion most likely derived from which of the following cell types?
questions.solution:
This patient has sarcoma botryoides, a subtype of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is a type of malignant mesenchymal tumor with skeletal muscle differentiation. The main subtypes include alveolar, embryonal, and pleomorphic. Most embryonal rhabdomyosarcomas are the sarcoma botryoides subtype.  

The name sarcoma botryoides derives from the Greek word botrys, which means “a bunch of grapes” due to its appearance. It is the most common vaginal malignancy in children and arises almost exclusively in girls younger than 5 years. It may also arise within the wall of the bladder. On histology, it is composed of rhabdomyoblasts arranged in sheets or nests. Rhabdomyosarcomas are aggressive tumors that usually require treatment with surgery and chemotherapy, with or without radiation therapy. The botryoid variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma is associated with the best prognosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Striated muscle:
 Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Smooth muscle :
Incorrect: Lesions that arise from smooth muscle include leiomyoma (benign) and leiomyosarcoma (malignant). This patient’s lesion is more consistent with another diagnosis.  
❌ Stratified squamous :
Incorrect: Lesions that arise from stratified squamous cells include papilloma (benign), squamous cell carcinoma (malignant), and epidermoid carcinoma (malignant). This patient’s lesion is more consistent with another diagnosis.  
❌ Melanocytes:
Incorrect: Lesions that arise from melanocytes include nevus (benign) and malignant melanoma (malignant). This patient’s lesion is more consistent with another diagnosis.  
❌ Endothelium:
Incorrect: Lesions that arise from the endothelium lining of blood vessels include hemangioma (benign) and angiosarcoma (malignant). This patient’s lesion is more consistent with another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, G2P1, comes to the emergency department in active labor. She has not received prenatal care during this pregnancy. A 3500g boy is delivered by an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows low-set ears, micrognathia and clenched fingers. Abdominal examination shows a midline non-reducible mass covered by a whitish membrane. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's abdominal findings?

choices.text: Failure of lateral body fold fusion

questions.solution:
This newborn infant boy has a midline non-reducible mass covered in a whitish membrane, which is consistent with omphalocele. Omphalocele is often associated with other anomalies, including chromosomal (e.g. trisomies 13 and 18), syndromic (e.g. Beckwith-Wiedemann) and other structural anomalies (e.g., cardiac, genitourinary, neural tube). This patient has low set ears, micrognathia and clenched fingers, and therefore most likely has Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18).  

Both gastroschisis and omphalocele are ventral abdominal wall defects, and they can often be confused with each other. However, these are distinct clinical entities, with different presentations, embryologic causes, and outcomes. During embryological development, the four body folds (rostral, caudal, and two lateral folds) fuse to form a normal abdominal wall. Omphalocele occurs when lateral folds fail to migrate and fuse at the umbilical ring. This failure causes the abdominal contents to remain persistently herniated into the umbilicus instead of returning to the abdominal cavity during the 10th week of embryological development. The abdominal contents are midline as they protrude through the umbilicus, and are covered with peritoneum.   

Gastroschisis occurs when the abdominal wall fails to close normally, and it is believed to be due to disrupted blood flow to the developing abdominal wall. The intestines are not covered with peritoneum and protrude typically to the right of the umbilicus. This condition is usually an isolated defect, with approximately 10% having an associated anomaly.
 


Both defects can be detected early in pregnancy via ultrasound, and an elevated maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) can also be seen (higher in gastroschisis than omphalocele). Both can be treated with surgical repair after birth. The overall survival with gastroschisis is over 90%, while survival in omphalocele is lower mainly due to associated anomalies.  

Option Analysis

❌ Persistence of the vitelline duct :
Incorrect: Persistence of the vitelline duct (omphalomesenteric) is the cause of Meckel diverticulum. The vitelline duct joins the yolk sac to the midgut lumen of the developing fetus. It may contain ectopic acid-secreting gastric mucosa and/or pancreatic tissue and can present with pain, hematochezia (bloody feces), intussusception, and/or volvulus. It does not present with a sack protruding through the abdominal wall. 
❌ Failure of urachus involution :
Incorrect: The urachus is a duct that connects the fetal bladder and the umbilicus. Failure of urachus to involute can cause a patent urachus, urachal cyst, or vesicoureteral diverticulum. In the case of a patent urachus, the patient would have urine coming out of the umbilicus. A urachal cyst would present with a painful mass below the umbilicus. 
✅ Failure of lateral body fold fusion :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Failure of umbilical ring closure :
Incorrect: Improper closure of the umbilical ring after reduction of the intestines during embryological development results in an umbilical hernia. The hernia is usually reducible, asymptomatic, and resolves in the first few years of life. In contrast to omphalocele, in which the body folds fail to fuse, in umbilical hernias, the body folds develop properly. The physiologic midgut herniation persists and results in a simple hernia that is covered by the skin. 
❌ Failure of gut rotation  :
Incorrect: Failure of the gut to rotate is the cause of intestinal malrotation. During 4th-8th week of embryonic development, there is physiologic extrusion and reduction of the gut through the umbilical ring. The gut performs 270°-degree rotation around the axis of the superior mesenteric artery. The abnormal position of the gut is termed malrotation. It does not cause a protrusion through the abdominal wall.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to delayed growth. His parents report that he is often bullied in school, because he is much smaller than his peers. He was at the 50th percentile for weight and height one year ago, but he is now at the 20th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows decreased vision in the lateral eye fields of both eyes. Magnetic resonance imaging is obtained and shows cystic lesions with areas of calcifications within the suprasellar region. This patient’s lesion is most likely a derivative of which of the embryological layers?
questions.solution:
This patient, who presents with growth delay, bitemporal hemianopsia and imaging showing a suprasellar cystic calcified mass, most likely has a craniopharyngioma.  

Craniopharyngiomas are benign, low grade tumors with a bimodal age distribution. Clinical features typically include headaches, endocrine abnormalities (deficiencies of growth hormone, gonadotropins, thyroid stimulating hormone, and/or adrenocorticotropic hormone), and bitemporal hemianopsia (compression of the optic chiasm). Imaging reveals a cystic, calcified parasellar lesion; histological analysis shows cysts filled with turbid “motor oil”-like fluid and cells filled with keratin (“keratin pearls”).  

Craniopharyngiomas arise from remnants of Rathke's pouch. During embryological development, the surface ectoderm forms the oropharynx. The small outpouching of the roof of the oropharynx, termed Rathke's pouch, gives rise to the adenohypophysis (anterior pituitary).  



Option Analysis

❌ Neural tube:
Incorrect: The neural tube is a hollow structure formed by the invagination of the neuroectoderm and gives rise to various central nervous system components, as seen in the table below. Prominent intracranial tumors that arise from the neural tube include glioblastoma multiforme, oligodendrogliomas, pilocytic astrocytomas, and ependymomas.   
✅ Surface ectoderm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Neural crest  :
Incorrect: The neural crest is derived from the neural plate, which itself is derived from the neuroectoderm. Prominent intracranial tumors that arise from neural crest cells include schwannomas and meningiomas.   
❌ Endoderm:
Incorrect: The endoderm is the innermost layer of the 3 primary germ layers and gives rise to the epithelial lining of various organs, which can be seen in the table below.   
❌ Mesoderm:
Incorrect: The mesoderm is the middle layer of the 3 primary germ layers and its various derivatives can be seen in the table below. Prominent structures that are found in the central nervous system include the dura mater (the only layer of the meninges that is not derived from the neural crest) as well as the notochord, which becomes the nucleus pulposus of intervertebral discs.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, comes to the labor and delivery unit in active labor. She did not receive prenatal care. The estimated gestation age is 25 weeks based on last menstrual period. The mother did not take prenatal vitamins. She did not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs during the pregnancy. Twenty minutes later, she gives birth to a stillborn male. An autopsy is performed and reveals the following:    



Retrieved from: Wikipedia

A defect in which of the following processes during embryogenesis most likely led to this condition?

choices.text: Failure of the primordial brain to divide
Failure of neural crest cell migration
Failure of the facial processes to fuse
Failure of fusion of the lateral palatine shelves

questions.solution:
This autopsy shows a classic picture of anencephaly, a severe developmental defect typified by failure of the forebrain and variable amounts of the brainstem to develop properly. The calvaria is open without overlying skin, exposing the cranial neural tube.  The condition is incompatible with life, and infants are either stillborn or die in the first few hours/days of life.  

The central nervous system starts to develop from an area of thickened ectoderm, known as the neural plate, around the 3rd week of embryonic life. Later, the lateral edges of the neural plate enlarge to form the neural folds and fuse into the neural tube. The fusion process begins in the cervical area and continues in both the rostral and caudal directions. Anencephaly is due to failure of the rostral neuropore to close around postovulatory day 25. These pregnancies are often complicated by polyhydramnios because the part of the brain responsible for swallowing is absent, resulting in increased fluid in the amniotic sac (polyhydramnios).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Failure of the primordial brain to divide:
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathogenesis behind holoprosencephaly, a developmental disorder in which the prosencephalon (the forebrain) fails to divide into two hemispheres. Instead, this picture is consistent with anencephaly.  
❌ Failure of neural crest cell migration:
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathogenesis behind Hirschsprung disease, a congenital defect that is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells/enteric nervous plexuses (Auerbach and Meissner plexuses) in the distal colon. Infants with Hirschsprung disease typically present with bilious emesis, abdominal distention, and failure to pass meconium.   
✅ Failure of neuropore to close  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Failure of the facial processes to fuse :
Incorrect: This answer describes the defect underlying craniofacial clefts, a facial deformity characterized by a gap or excess tissue of bone and/or soft tissue. This condition is associated with airway/breathing deficits, as well as feeding and speech deficits. Unlike the anencephaly seen in this newborn, craniofacial clefts are compatible with life.   
❌ Failure of fusion of the lateral palatine shelves  :
Incorrect: This answer describes the defect underlying cleft palate. Another cause of this condition involves failure of the palatine shelf to fuse with the nasal septum and/or the primary palate (formation of 2° palate). Instead, this picture is consistent with anencephaly.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents to her pediatrician for a routine check up. She is doing well in school, but her friends have been making fun of her since she has not “hit puberty yet.” Past medical history is noncontributory, and she does not use any illicit substances. She is currently not taking any medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 156/71 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination is notable for tanner stage I of development. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with the absence of secondary sex characteristics and hypertension, which is consistent with a diagnosis of 17α-hydroxylase deficiency. This disease manifests with absent secondary sex characteristics in females due to decreased levels of androstenedione.  

17α-hydroxylase deficiency is a subtype of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, which are a series of autosomal recessive enzymatic deficiency disorders that affect mineralocorticoid, glucocorticoid, and sex hormone synthesis. Specifically, 17α-hydroxylase deficiency results in impaired synthesis of androgens, estrogens, and cortisol--but does not affect mineralocorticoid production. Mineralocorticoids 11-deoxycorticosterone and corticosterone are significantly elevated in this disorder, resulting in hypertension. In females, most are asymptomatic until puberty, when they fail to develop secondary sex characteristics or are unable to become pregnant. In males, the disease is usually detected much earlier due to the presence of ambiguous genitalia or undescended testes.  

Diagnosis is achieved via measuring excessively high plasma levels of 11-deoxycorticosterone and corticosterone, genetic testing, and enzymatic assays for confirmation. Management involves glucocorticoid replacement without mineralocorticoid replacement.



Option Analysis

✅ Decreased levels of androstenedione:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased levels of androstenedione:
Incorrect: Increased androstenedione levels are associated with 21-hydroxylase and 11β-hydroxylase deficiency. These conditions will manifest with symptoms of virilization (e.g., increased facial hair, increased muscle mass, acne) in females. In contrast, this patient lacks such symptoms.
❌ Increased renin activity:
Incorrect: Increased renin activity is associated with 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which manifests with hypotension and virilization in females. In contrast, this patient has hypertension and lacks signs of virilization (e.g., increased facial hair, increased muscle mass, acne).
❌ Increased levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone:
Incorrect: Elevated levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone are observed in 21-hydroxylase deficiency and 11β-hydroxylase deficiency. Both disorders will manifest with virilization in females. In contrast, this patient does not have signs of virilization (e.g., increased facial hair, increased muscle mass, acne).
❌ Increased levels of 11-deoxycorticosterone only:
Incorrect: Elevated levels of 11-deoxycorticosterone without elevated levels of corticosterone are observed in patients with 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, which manifests with hypertension and virilization. Although this patient has hypertension, she does not have signs of virilization.

questions.text: A 2-day-old infant girl is observed to have several episodes of bilious vomiting while in the nursery. The vomiting occurs shortly after feeding. She was born full-term to a 38-year-old, gravida 2 para 2, female via vaginal delivery. The pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. The patient’s vitals are notable for hypotension and tachycardia. Examination of the skull reveals sunken anterior and posterior fontanelles. The patient is also observed to have upslanted palpebral fissure and prominent epicanthal folds. A single transverse palmar crease is noted on the bilateral hands. The patient has a scaphoid abdomen. Digital rectal examination reveals normal rectal tone and no expulsion of gas or stool. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Ischemia and reabsorption of the jejunum
Failure of the duodenum to recanalize
Impaired neural crest cell migration into the intestinal walls
Abnormal rotation of the small intestines

questions.solution:
This patient has duodenal atresia, a condition associated with trisomy 21. During embryological development, the primitive gut tube undergoes a solid stage where proliferating cells fill it up. Normally, the gut subsequently undergoes recanalization, and the lumen re-forms. If recanalization fails in the region giving rise to the duodenum, the result is duodenal atresia.  

A similar condition is jejunal/ileal atresia, which occurs when ischemia causes necrosis and reabsorption of portions of the gut tube. The condition is associated with cystic fibrosis.  

Both conditions result in a blind pouch and intestinal obstruction. In utero, these conditions cause polyhydramnios. After birth, these conditions cause difficulty feeding and vomiting. The vomitus can be non-bilious or bilious depending on whether the obstruction is proximal/distal to the major duodenal papilla, respectively. Additionally, patients with duodenal atresia can develop biliary atresia and annular pancreas because the region of the embryonic gut giving rise to the duodenum also gives rise to the pancreas and hepatobiliary tree.    
Both conditions are diagnosed by radiography. Duodenal atresia causes the “double-bubble sign”, where both the duodenum and nearby stomach are filled with air. Jejunal atresia causes the “triple-bubble sign,” where the jejunum is also dilated.
 

This abdominal radiograph shows the classic “double bubble” sign with a gas-filled distended stomach and duodenum and an absence of distal gas
Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Option Analysis

❌ Ischemia and reabsorption of the jejunum :
Incorrect: This answer describes the underlying cause of jejunal atresia, which is associated with cystic fibrosis. In contrast, this patient’s physical exam findings of upslanted palpebral fissures, prominent epicanthal folds, and single transverse palmar creases are consistent with trisomy 21. Patients with trisomy 21 are at increased risk of developing duodenal atresia. 
✅ Failure of the duodenum to recanalize :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  Hypertrophy of the pyloric sphincter :
Incorrect: This answer describes hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. However, the condition would cause non-bilious vomiting, since the pyloric sphincter is before the duodenal papilla, the location of bile secretion.  
❌ Impaired neural crest cell migration into the intestinal walls :
Incorrect: This answer describes Hirschsprung disease. Patients with trisomy 21 are at increased risk of developing the condition, and Hirschsprung disease can cause bilious vomiting. However, it would also cause a distended abdomen, since stool cannot be eliminated, as opposed to a scaphoid abdomen. Additionally, neonates with Hirschsprung disease typically have a positive squirt sign (expulsion of stool on digital rectal examination), as well as increased rectal tone, neither of which are seen in this patient. 
❌ Abnormal rotation of the small intestines :
Incorrect: Malrotation of the intestines can lead to a midgut volvulus. It can cause intestinal obstruction, vomiting, and a distended abdomen. However, many of this patient’s physical examination findings (e.g., prominent epicanthal folds, single transverse palmar crease) are consistent with trisomy 21, which predisposes patients to developing duodenal atresia.
